page.title: 01UPPIES AND DOWNIES
page.content: Uppies and Downies is a traditional game played at Easter for as long as anyone can remember. The game is played on the Cloffocks field. The aim is for the Uppies to ground, or 'hail', the ball at Curwen Hall and for the Downies to hail it at the quay of the harbour.There are no rules and no teams (anyone can join in, if they dare).The ball is made of leather, stuffed with phlox. The sponsors of the game for about 500 years have been the Daglish family The shortest games last only a few minutes, but the longest lasted until 3 o-clock in the morning. Although most games are fairly law abiding, there have been deaths, including drowning in the river Derwent.Local shopkeepers along the route board up their windows. The long tradition goes on!.
